Award.AwardTitle: The 2017 Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "2017 Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS)" that will be held from May 22-26, 2017, on the campus of Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, Texas.

This conference is the 2017 version of the Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium, a series that has been an annual major operator algebras and operator theory meeting since 1981. The meeting will be of broad scope and of interest to the full operator theory and operator algebras communities with well over 100 participants expected. Topics to be highlighted in the 2017 meeting include the following: the corona problem; Hilbert modules; noncommutative function theory; deformation-rigidity; subfactors and fusion categories; classification of C*-algebras; C*-algebras and dynamical systems: the Baum-Connes conjecture; noncommutative differential geometry; index theory; operator spaces. The format of the meeting with plenary lectures and contributed talks allows participants to learn of the latest developments from world leaders and provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and junior investigator to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual meeting of the Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS) was held on the campus of Texas Christian University (TCU) in Fort Worth, Texas on May 22 – 26, 2017.  The conference was largely funded by National Science Foundation grant DMS-1700164.  The members of the Organizing Committee were José Carrión (TCU) and Efton Park (TCU).

Speakers: The meeting featured sixteen plenary speakers with national and international reputations:

  1.             Nate Brown (Penn State University)
  2.             George Elliott (University of Toronto)
  3.             Thierry Giordano (University of Ottawa)
  4.             Adrian Ioana (University of California at San Diego)
  5.             Jens Kaad (Syddansk Universitet)
  6.             Mehrdad Kalantar (University of Houston)
  7.             David Kerr (Texas A&M University)
  8.             Nadia Larsen (University of Oslo)
  9.             Terry Loring (University of New Mexico)
  10.             John McCarthy (Washington University)
  11.             Paul Muhly (University of Iowa)
  12.             Gelu Popescu (University of Texas at San Antonio)
  13.             Sarah Reznikoff (Kansas State University)
  14.             David Sherman (University of Virginia)
  15.             Roger Smith (Texas A&M University)
  16.             Mark Tomforde (University of Houston)

Each of the sixteen speakers gave a 50-minute lecture.

In addition to the plenary lectures, there were 47 contributed talks, each 20 minutes long; fourteen of these were given by graduate students.

 

Demographic Information: There were 108 attendees at the meeting, including the two organizers.  Here is a breakdown in terms of gender, ethnicity, and position: 

Gender:

  • Female – 14
  • Male – 94

Ethnicity (only 69 participants opted to respond):

  •  Asian – 13
  • Hispanic – 3
  • White non-Hispanic – 53

Position:

  • Faculty (tenured, tenure track, instructor) – 52
  • Postdoctoral Fellow – 13
  • Graduate Student – 43

The conference participants represented nine countries, 23 states, and 47 institutions of higher learning.
